definition:
As noted by van der Waerden, it is possible to define the notion of
dependence axiomatically in such a way that one can deal with linear
dependence, algebraic dependence, and other sorts of dependence via a
general theory. In this general theoretical framework, one can prove
results about bases, dimension, and the like.

Let $S$ be a set. The basic object of this theory is a relation $D$
between $S$ and the power set of $S$. This relation satisfies the
following three axioms:

If $Y$ is a subset of $S$ and $x \in Y$, then $D(x,Y)$.

If, for some set $X \subseteq S$ and some $y,z \in S$, it happens that
$D(y,X \cup \{z\})$ but not $D(y,X)$, then $D(z, X \cup \{y\})$.

If, for some sets $Y,Z \subseteq S$ and some $x \in S$, it happens that
$D(x,Y)$ and, for every $y \in Y$, it is the case that $D(y,Z)$, then
$D(x,Z)$.
